It is here that the 11 women in the Florecitas Trust Bank meet to receive a loan from Friendship Bridge. For some, it will be their very first loan, and for others, it will be another loan cycle. For the most part, they are dressed in traditional dress and speak exclusively in Kiche. 

The women in the Florecitas Trust Bank group are motivated. They chose the name Florecitas, meaning little flowers, because they believe with the support of Friendship Bridge and Kiva investors, they will be able to grow their businesses and personal lives into something beautiful.

Lucia, the president of the trust bank, is an example of this. She only had the chance to go to school through third grade, but all four of her children graduated from high school. She has created three businesses, but she is currently focusing on her business buying and reselling huipiles and cortes (traditional outfits). She will use the loan to increase her inventory and selection of huipils and cortes. She also wants to buy thread and materials to make more products. 

The women are rooted in their traditions, but they are progressive in their thoughts and actions. All of the women believe in themselves as women, their power as individuals, and as businesswomen. They work as hard as they do in part to provide for their families and to make sure their daughters and sons have more opportunities than they did.

loans.use: to buy more materials to make traditional huipiles (blouses) and cortes (skirts) to sell

loans.name: Nyonmo Bei Group

texts.en:
The Nyonmo Bei group is made up of people from the same neighborhood. They average 30 years old. They live in Teshie, Accra and know each other from neighborhood ties. 

All the people engage in small scale commerce, selling wigs, perming creams, earrings, children's clothing, underwear, provisions, vegetables, and frozen food. 

In order to increase their business funds, the members of the group decided to collaborate with ID Ghana. They are on their first group loan.

Olivia has a good reputation selling vegetables like cabbage, onions, lettuce, and carrots. She plans to use her loan to buy more vegetables like cabbage, onions, lettuce,and carrots from the market and sell to customers. 

With her loan, Olivia hopes to earn a good monthly profit which will be reinvested in her business. She is 39 years old, single, and has two children who depend on her. 

They will hold each other for responsible for repayment of this loan.

loans.use: to buy more vegetables (cabbage, onions, lettuce, carrots) from the market and sell to customers.

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena is 25 years old and unmarried with two children. 

She has a small garden where she grows taro and bananas that she can sell in her community or at the market. She has been doing this for two years. 

Elena needs a loan to buy chemicals, a new wheelbarrow, a farming fork, a tiller, a crowbar, a spade, new gloves, and crops. She has been a member of South Pacific Business Development (SPBD) since 2014. 

She will use the profits from her sales to pay for her family's weekly expenses.

loans.use: to buy chemicals, a new wheelbarrow, a farming fork, a tiller, a crowbar, a spade, new gloves, and crops.

loans.name: Lili

texts.en:
Lili is 43 years old and married with six children. 

She has a small garden where she grows taro and yams that she can sell in her community or at the market. She has been doing this for three years. 

Lili needs a loan to buy a wheelbarrow, a spade, a machete, a shovel, chemicals, gum boots, and a new sprayer. She has been a member of South Pacific Business Development (SPBD) since 2011. 

She will use the profits from her sales to pay for her children's education.

loans.use: to buy a wheelbarrow, a spade, a machete, a shovel, chemicals, gum boots, and a new sprayer.

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
As a way of generating income, Gina has engaged in cooking and selling street foods in her community for almost a year now. She is 58 years of age and blessed with three children. Her husband, Oscar, works as an electrician and they work hand-in-hand to provide for their needs.

In the Philippines, the whole working community and most of the families only eat home-cooked meals during evenings when all of the family members are at home to take part in the meal. This is not only a usual family tradition, but a matter of convenience and frugal living. It is considered a waste of money and time to spend cooking gas and food for one to two persons when buying cooked rice and viands cost less than raw food. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of PHP 500 in sales everyday.

Gina plans to cook and sell burgers and more snack recipes, but she doesn't have enough capital. For this reason, she would like to request a loan amount of 12,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) to buy additional raw products like pork and chicken and seasonings that are needed. Being a kind and friendly mother, she is hoping that she will further improve the business through this financial assistance.

Gina dreams to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

*All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for raw ingredients like bread, burgers, pork, chicken, vegetables and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Asuisui

texts.en: Asuisui is a 69-year-old widowed woman with nine children. She makes and sells baked breadfruit, taro, yams and bananas in her community to earn a living. She has 10 years of experience with this business. Asuisui needs a loan to buy bananas, breadfruit, taro, yams, plastic bags, large pots, a new table, a bag of salt and foil. She plans to use her profits to expand her business and pay for her family's weekly expenses. Asuisui has been a member of SPBD since 2004.

loans.use: to buy bananas, breadfruit, taro, yams, plastic bags, large pots, a new table, a bag of salt and foil

loans.name: Selepa

texts.en: Selepa is a 52-year-old married woman with seven children. She makes and sells meat pies in her community to earn a living. She has two years of experience with this business. Selepa needs a loan to buy meat, soy sauce, a large pot, chinese onions, spring onions, salt, a gab of flour and a small oven. She plans to use her profits to pay for her children's education. Selepa has been a member of SPBD since 2014.

loans.use: to buy meat, soy sauce, a large pot, chinese onions, spring onions, salt, a gab of flour and a small oven

loans.name: Segia

texts.en:
Segia is 34-years-old and married with five children.  She has a small plantation and grows taro and bananas that she can sell in her community or at the market. She has been doing this for 4 years. Segia needs a loan to buy chemicals, sprayers, a spade, fertilizer, a tiller, a wheelbarrow and new boots. 

She has been a member of SPBD since 2010. Segia will use the profits from her sales to pay for her family's weekly expenses.

loans.use: to buy chemicals, sprayers, a spade, fertilizer, a tiller, a wheelbarrow and new boots

loans.name: Robert

texts.en: Robert is a forty six year old male. He is married with eight children, who are between the ages of 11 to 17. He has a cattle fattening business. Robert sells milk to add to his income. He started this business in 1998 to cater to his family's needs. However, he is challenged by inadequate capital. Robert is requesting a loan to buy cows for fattening.

loans.use: to buy cows for fattening.

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en:
As a way of generating income, Carmelita has been engaged in a variety store business within her community for almost 15 years now. She is 56 years of age and blessed with two children. Her husband, Apolonio, helps her with their business and they work hand-in-hand to provide for their needs.

In the Philippines, a variety store is a retail store that sells inexpensive items, often with a single price for all items in the store. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 500 in sales every day.

Due to financial insufficiency, Carmelita wants to make her business more profitable in order to earn a higher income. For this reason, she would like to request a loan amounting to 50,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) to buy additional grocery items that are needed. Being a kind and friendly mother, she is hoping that she will further improve the business through this financial assistance.

Carmelita aspires to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

*All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Leautlai

texts.en: Leatulai is a 57-year-old woman who is married with four children. She has a small taxi business to earn a living. She has 12 years in this business. Leatulai needs a loan to buy a taxi sign, new tires, engine oil, new seat covers, floor mats and a new paint job. She will use her profits to pay for her family’s weekly expenses and to renovate her house. Leatulai joined SPBD in 2002 to gain access to financial services.

loans.use: to buy a taxi sign, new tires, engine oil, new seat covers, floor mats and a new paint job.

loans.name: Talani

texts.en: Talani is a 47-year-old widow with five children. She makes and sells sandwiches, donuts, pies and coffee in her community to earn a living. She has five years of experience with this business. Talani needs a loan to buy a large boiler, sugar, coffee, bread, butter, jam, and bags of flour and yeast. She plans to use her profits for the betterment of her business. Talani has been a member of SPBD since 2009.

loans.use: to buy a large boiler, sugar, coffee, bread, butter, jam, and bags of flour and yeast

loans.name: Eseta

texts.en: Eseta is a 36-year-old married woman with five children. She makes and sells a variety of snacks in her community to earn a living. She has five years of experience with this business. Eseta needs a loan to buy bread, cans of tuna fish, mayonnaise, butter, lettuce, purple sandwich onions, salt and a large portable sandwich maker. She plans to use her profits to pay for her children's education. Eseta has been a member of SPBD since 2009.

loans.use: to buy bread, cans of tuna fish, mayonnaise, butter, lettuce, purple sandwich onions, salt and a large portable sandwich maker

loans.name: Salome

texts.en: Salome is a 36-year-old, single woman with three children. She owns and operates a small store, selling a variety of items. She has been doing this for three years. Salome needs a loan to buy a new display fridge, a chest freezer, a bag of flour, sugar and rice. She hopes to use her profits to expand her house and to pay for her children's education. She became a member of SPBD in 2011 to gain access to capital for her business.

loans.use: to buy a new display fridge, a chest freezer, flour, sugar and rice.

loans.name: Violet

texts.en:
Violet is a 37-year-old married woman who supports a family of five children and the husband adds an additional income to support their family upkeep.  She has been operating a brick making business for a period of ten years earning an income of KES 5,000.

She is now requesting her second loan of KES 10,000 with VisionFund Kenya and intends to use this amount to construct a permanent building where she will be able to store the bricks to prevent them from being damaged or destroyed.

Violet plans to use the anticipated income to educate her children and live a stable life.  It is her hope that she will own a hardware store in the near future and become a successful business woman.

loans.use: To have capital to make more bricks to sell to her clients

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: she will use the loan to buy more goods such as rice, oil, batteries, bouillon cubes, etc.

loans.name: Fatima

texts.en: Fatima is a 24-year-old unwed woman with two children. She makes and sells a variety of snacks in her community to earn a living. She has two years of experience with this business. Fatima needs a loan to buy sandwiches, donuts, pies, bread, coffee, sugar, milk and a large boiler. She plans to use her profits to pay for her children's education. Fatima has been a member of SPBD since 2012.

loans.use: to buy sandwiches, donuts, pies, bread, coffee, sugar, milk and a large boiler

loans.name: Milagros

texts.en:
This is Milagros. She is 51-years-old and currently resides with her husband, Norberto, in Manila, Philippines. She has been operating her own “sari-sari” (variety) store for more than two years, and she profits well from this. Having a bigger responsibility requires more effort to provide for her family's needs, especially for her children. She and her partner had to work hard, determined to have a better income, to provide their children with a better education.

In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 500 in sales every day.

To improve sales, Milagros would like to apply for a loan to purchase additional grocery goods to sell. At an amount of 12,000 PHP (Philippine Pesos), she could already purchase larger quantities and more varieties of grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business. She sincerely lets you know her heartfelt thanks and appreciation for this assistance in advance.

In the future, Milagros hopes to succeed in all that she is pursuing and dreams of a better life for her family. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members every week to share stories of her life and business and to draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God, which she studies. 

*All CCT (Center for Community Transformation Credit Cooperative) community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business

loans.name: Fiaoo

texts.en: Fiaoo is a 42-year-old, single woman with five children. She runs a small barbecue hut in her community to earn a living. She has two years of experience with this business. Fiaoo needs a loan to buy a new barbeque set, soya sauce, tongs, cases of chicken, mutton flaps, local sausages and plastic plates. She plans to use her profits to pay for her family’s weekly expenses. Fiaoo has been a member of SPBD since 2012.

loans.use: to buy a new barbecue set, soya sauce, tongs, cases of chicken, mutton flaps, local sausages and plastic plates.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: buy more meat with the money.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more goods like soft drinks, beer, stout, etc.

loans.name: Sivan Shg Group

texts.en: Given its abundance, firewood is a common domestic fuel in India, especially in rural households. Kumari, who hails from Mazvalanalur in Tamil Nadu, cooks food using a makeshift cook stove that runs on firewood. Many women living in her neighborhood are dependent on similar cook stoves and firewood. Unfortunately, these women are at the brink of contracting fatal lung diseases such as lung cancer, pneumonia, bronchitis, etc as they inhale a high volume of smoke emanating from burning firewood every day. Kumari has teamed up with five other women to purchase low smoke cook stoves available in the market and named their group “Sivan”, which refers to the lord Shiva. All these women earn a living with small livelihood activities. Their earnings are not sufficient to purchase the smokeless stoves. So, they are requesting a loan to buy low smoke cook stoves.

loans.use: a loan to buy smokeless cook stoves

loans.name: Iratairoja Self Help Group

texts.en:
Maharajapuram is a hamlet in Tamil Nadu. Priya, 30 years old, is living in this village with her husband Muthukumar who is a farmer. They have two children. She is the featured borrower of Iratairoja Self Help Group with eight other women. The group is managed by the local NGO “PAT”. They have been receiving loans from PAT for the last five years and are trying to improve their livelihoods.
 
Currently all members are using firewood convention stoves, mud cook stoves and indoor fires that emit greenhouse gases such as carbon dioxide, methane and carbon monoxide. They also emit 25% of all global black carbon emissions. Black carbon is the second worst contributor to global warming after CO2. Hence, members need a loan to purchase a smokeless stoves to use in their kitchen, which they feel will be very convenient for them in cooking as this emits less smoke and also saves money on their fuel .

loans.use: to purchase a smokeless stove

loans.name: Fialelei

texts.en: Fialelei is 45 years old and married with five children. She has a small plantation and grows taro and bananas that she can sell in her community or at the market. She has been doing this for five years. Fialelei needs a loan to buy chemicals, sprayers, fertilizer, a tiller, a farming fork, a crowbar, a spade and crops. She has been a member of SPBD since 2009. Fialelei will use the profits from her sales to help with her family's weekly expenses.

loans.use: to buy chemicals, sprayers, fertilizer, a tiller, a farming fork, a crowbar, a spade and crops

loans.name: Elieta

texts.en: Elieta is a 32-year-old single mother of three children. She makes and sells elei printed material to earn a living and has been doing this for two years. Elieta has requested a loan to buy material, fabric paint, brushes, rollers, stencils and a new cutter. She plans to use her profits to pay for her familiy's weekly expenses. She joined SPBD in 2014 to gain access to financial services.

loans.use: to buy material, fabric paint, brushes, rollers, stencils and a new cutter

loans.name: Ricardo

texts.en:
When Ricardo moved to the United States from Brazil with his wife and children, he needed a way to earn an income. A natural salesman, he noticed many granite businesses operating in the state of Massachusetts. When he heard about one store that was about to close, he decided to buy the granite business and work to revitalize it. 

Ricardo’s natural affinity for sales paid off as he saw revenue increasing every day. But Ricardo has big dreams for his business. He knows he can grow it if he could diversify his inventory and import goods from China and Korea. With this loan, he will be able to purchase different types of granite and expand his selection of materials.

“My dream is to enlarge my company and build stores throughout the Northeast. Personally, I would also like to earn an income to give my children a good education.”

Help this entrepreneur and father build his business and support his family!

loans.use: to diversify his inventory by importing granite from China and Korea.

loans.name: Ruhiyya

texts.en:
Ruhiyya is 37 years old. She is married and has three children. Her eldest child is 15 years old and is studying at first course of college. Another child is 13 years old and going to school and the youngest is 10 years old and also school aged. 

For more than 21 years, Ruhiyya has been an IDP (Internally Displaced Person) from her home, which was in Khojaly city. Now she is living in the Abseron region with her lovely family. 

Ruhiyya has been in the tailoring business for 12 years. She sews women's dresses, skirts, blouses, etc., and she also sews curtains by order. She receives orders from customers, prepares orders and earns money. 

Today she is planning to increase her working capital to buy new materials. For this reason she has applied to the Komak company for a loan in the amount of 2,100 AZN (Azerbaijan new manat). She is thankful to Kiva for the loan.

loans.use: to buy new materials.

loans.name: Folototo

texts.en:
Folototo is 28 years old and single, with four children. 

She has a small plantation and grows taro that she can sell in her community or at the market. She has been doing this for three years. 

Folototo needs a loan to buy chemicals, a wheelbarrow, a farming fork, a tiller, a crowbar, a spade, fertilizer, and crops. 

She has been a member of South Pacific Business Development (SPBD) since 2011. Folototo will use the profits from her sales to pay for her children's education.

loans.use: to buy chemicals, a wheelbarrow, a farming fork, a tiller, a crowbar, a spade, fertilizer, and crops.

loans.name: Sherif

texts.en:
After working in the youth sports industry for a few years, Sherif noticed a lack of options sports organizations had for merchandise. 

“Working with youth sports organizations has always been a passion of mine because of the critical life skills they offer their players,” explained Sherif.

Sherif created Team Fund Up, a business that provides wholesale sports gear/merchandise to local schools. Recently the business has grown to include local sporting goods stores, which has doubled his sales. Sherif’s proudest achievement is working with nonprofits to raise money critical to programs that help homeless individuals get off the streets and into jobs. 

However, Sherif has found it difficult to scale his business. Rent is high and equipment is expensive. With this loan, he will be able to purchase more equipment to increase productivity. 

“Professionally, this business has the potential to help over 100 million sports players raise money for their organizations to help those organizations grow in the community to provide more critical services to people in need of a positive outlet,” explains Sherif. 

Help Sherif build his business and encourage youth and adults to lead a healthy and active lifestyle!

loans.use: To purchase sports gear/merchandise

loans.name: Jenefer

texts.en:
Jenefer has run a variety store business n her community for 20 years. She is 36 years old and blessed with four children. Her husband, Ariel, works as a tricycle driver and they work hand-in-hand to provide for their family's needs.

In the Philippines, a variety store is a retail store that sells inexpensive items, often with a single price for all items in the store. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns income by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling them retail by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 500 in sales every day.

Jenefer wants to make her business more profitable to earn a higher income. For this reason, she would like to borrow 25,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) to buy additional grocery items. She is hoping that she will further improve the business through this financial assistance.

Jenefer dreams of becoming rich so that she could provide her family more than their everyday needs. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and also draws strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

*All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business

loans.name: Jerlie

texts.en:
Jerlie has run a direct-selling business within her community for almost nine years. She is 32 years old and blessed with four children. Her husband, Danny, works as a mason and they work hand-in-hand to provide for their family's needs.

She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products through popular direct-selling brands like Avon, Fuller life, Natasha, Boardwalk, and Marikina Shoe Exchange. A customer's order is bought in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with one-month-to-pay credit. Dealer’s prices are lower than those in the catalogue, so they earn profit from these transactions as their income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 2,000 in sales every week.

Jerlie wants to make her business more profitable to earn a higher income. For this reason, she would like borrow 32,000 PHP to buy additional merchandise like shampoo, cologne, deodorant, perfume, soap, fabric softener, undergarments and other products that are needed to increase her product inventory. She is hoping she will further improve the business through this financial assistance.

Jerlie dreams for her business to grow bigger and hopes to give her children a good life and education. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and also draws strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

*All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional supplies and merchandise like undergarments, deodorant, and cosmetics needed in her business.

loans.name: Ricardo

texts.en:
Ricardo moved to the United States from Colombia seeking economic opportunity. After working for a large tax firm for years, he decided to start his own tax company in the hopes of earning more for him and his two daughters. 

Ricardo’s business has quickly grown to service over 300 clients and he has hired one part-time assistant helping him with the workload.  However, in order to improve his efficiency, he needs to purchase additional office equipment to increase output. With this loan, he will be able to purchase a new computer and software for his part-time employee.
 
Help Ricardo grow his business and provide for his two daughters!

loans.use: To purchase a new computer and software for his tax company.

loans.name: Kenneth

texts.en:
Kenneth always loved eccentric jewelry, but he found there was never enough of a selection for men. The pieces he did find always ranged from $1,000 and up, and as a college student, he was never able to dig that deeply into his own pockets.  He decided to start designing for himself. When others became interested in his designs, he decided to start his own business, Smithstonean Customs. 

“I have always loved art and fashion, and this was the perfect way to culminate them into a livelihood,” said Kenneth.

Kenneth’s talent for jewelry design has earned him much recognition. The company has been featured alongside Gucci and Prada in The Source Magazine. His designs are being carried on Karmaloop.com, the largest online urban retailer in the world. He was recently invited to exhibit at the 2014 Grammys and Oscars. However, in order to do so, he needs the capital to manufacture his new collection.

With this loan, Kenneth will be able to manufacture his new collection and participate at the Liberty Fair fashion trade show, which will help him gain major retail accounts with powerhouses such as Niemen Marcus. 

Help this talented entrepreneur build his vision!

loans.use: To manufacture his new jewelry collection and exhibit at a trade show

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John resides in Hoima, Uganda. He is 39 years old, married, with six children aged between 14 and 4; five of them attend school. 

John does farming and works eight hours a day. John gets additional income from motorcycle repairing. His aim is to improve on his household income and to educate his children, although he lacks sufficient capital.

John is acquiring a loan to plant onions, maize, and beans.

loans.use: to plant onions, maize, and beans.

loans.name: Ohmsakthi Shg Group

texts.en:
Rajeswari, Jothilakshmi, Ganthimathy, Dhanam and Kalaiselvi are the group members of “Ohmsakthi” Self Help Group. Rajeswari is the featured borrower of this group. She is the lady sitting in the picture.

Rajeswari is from Gunamangalam village in Tamil Nadu. She is married and has two children. Her husband is a farmer. She has a firewood conventional stove in her kitchen that emits carbon dioxide. The fire creates immediately tangible, undesirable effects including stinging eyes, scratchy throats and coughs. The house walls are covered in soot and dirt. Rajeswari and her family members are all affected by this. A remedy to this situation is a smokeless stove for which she is requesting a loan.

loans.use: to buy a smokeless stove

loans.name: Dana

texts.en:
With a degree in child development, Dana has always known that she wanted to continue working with children in some way. When Dana found herself laid off a few years back, she seized the opportunity to change directions in her career. 

While flipping through a community college catalog, Dana stumbled upon classes to become a supervised monitor for families that have been separated due to various reasons.  She decided to take the plunge and after completing her certification, she started her own visitations and transfers business. Part of Dana’s services include observing and documenting visits between non-custodial parents and their children, helping families stick together even through difficult circumstances. Dana loves supporting these families, and has already helped five families since starting her business six months ago.

The main challenge that Dana has faced in getting her business off the ground is getting her name out there. Most of her business comes through word of mouth and existing relationships, so it has been difficult for her to have consistent work. However, Dana is confident that once enough lawyers and families know about her exceptional services, she will be able to build a stable client base.

This Kiva loan will help Dana to purchase a new computer and perform much needed car maintenance to keep it safe for transporting the families she works with. Dana is also working on a flier to market her business and hopes some additional marketing will increase her exposure. 

To support her start-up, Dana is also currently teaching at a preschool but hopes to eventually be able to grow her business to the point where she could do it full-time.

loans.use: to purchase a new computer, run marketing and perform much needed car maintenance

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is a 19-year-old single woman with no children. She makes and sells a variety of snacks in her community to earn a living. She has two years of experience with this business. Grace needs a loan to buy bread, cans of tuna, mayonnaise, butter, lettuce, tomatoes, salt, pepper and a box of tissue. She plans to use her profits to pay for her family's weekly expenses. Grace has been a member of SPBD since 2014.

loans.use: to buy bread, cans of tuna, mayonnaise, butter, lettuce, tomatoes, salt, pepper and a box of tissue

loans.name: Taulau

texts.en:
Taulau is a 49-year-old divorced woman with nine children. She makes and sells sandwiches, donuts, pies, snacks and coffee in her community to earn a living. She has four years of experience with this business. 

Taulau needs a loan to buy bread, butter, jam, cans of tuna, lettuce, flour, yeast, sugar, milk and coffee. She plans to use her profits to pay for her children's education. Taulau has been a member of SPBD since 2014.

loans.use: to buy bread, butter, jam, cans of tuna, lettuce, flour, yeast, sugar, milk and coffee for her foodstall

loans.name: Sevvanthi Shg Group

texts.en:
Manimegalai (the lady who is standing with her hand raised) is a member of “Sevvanthi” Self Help Group consisting of 10 women who all live in Anaikkarai of Tanjore district of Tamilnadu along with their children and husbands. They make a living by their doing various small income generating activities.

These hardworking women, before commencing their business every morning, prepare breakfast and lunch for their families using primitive cook stoves that operate on firewood. They prepare dinner after closing their businesses in the night. They spend 3-4 hours every day cooking, inhaling harmful smoke released by the burning of firewood. They are worried about endangering themselves and other family members to diseases such as bronchitis, lung cancer, and pneumonia. 

These women don’t want to turn a blind eye towards the adversities of using the primitive cook stoves. Rather, they wish to replace the old cook stoves with new, low-smoke ones. However, their marginal savings every month are not sufficient. So, they wish to procure a loan of to purchase a cook stove and repay the loan amount within the stipulated time period.

loans.use: to buy a smokeless stove.

loans.name: Denish

texts.en:
Denish is 36 and sells general merchandise like sugar and sweets to the general public. Denish also does farming and runs a motorcycle transport business to supplement his income. He started his retail business three years ago with hopes of having a bigger household income base and of trading wholesale. However, he faces a challenge of competition and inadequate capital to expand his business.
He is requesting a loan to buy sugar, sweets and toothpaste to sell.

loans.use: to general merchandise like sugar, sweets and toothpaste to sell.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter lives in Masindi and sells general merchandise to the people living in his area. He also has a motorcycle transport business to supplement his income. He ventured into the retail business to support his needs and especially to educate his children. Peter hopes to improve his business and educate his children since he himself didn't attain education due to lack of school fees. However, he faces a challenge of competition and price fluctuations just like other traders dealing in retail.
Peter needs a loan to sugar, posho and cooking oil for selling.

loans.use: to buy sugar, posho (cornmeal staple) and cooking oil for selling.

loans.name: Bharathi Shg Group

texts.en:
Ambika, along with five other married women from Vilangudi village in Tamil Nadu, formed a group called “Bharathi” with the help of the local NGO “PAT”. They have taken loans before from PAT to improve their livelihood and have repaid them on time. 

Until now, Ambika has been relying on an old cook stove that runs on firewood to prepare food for her family. She spends 3 to 4 hours every day in front of this cook stove.  She is directly exposed to heat and smoke emitted from the burner, making her and her kids prone to various lung diseases. 
After struggling for many years, she has finally decided to bring an end to this daily ordeal by purchasing an improved cook stove that produces low smoke. However her income from the various petty businesses they run is not sufficient to purchase a cooking stove. So she, along with the other women, is requesting a loan to buy this cooking stove.

loans.use: to buy a smokeless stove

loans.name: Yiriwa Group

texts.fr:
Yiriwa est un regroupement de femmes du quartier Hamdallaye de la ville de Koutiala qui se connaissent bien et qui vivent dans de grandes familles traditionnelles avec leurs maris, enfants et autres parents. Elles ont en moyenne 36 ans, sont mariées et ont au moins 3 enfants.
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles divers tels que, des Habits, Condiment et divers. Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso. Elles sont à leur treizième prêt de groupe. 
Bintou  est un membre du groupe Yiriwa assise deuxième personne de droite à gauche, vendeuse de Soumbala.  Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter de Soumbala au marché en quantité et en qualité qu’elle vend en détail  à une clientèle diverse.. 
Tandis que les autres membres du groupe Yiriwa comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 130 000FCFA  chacune au  cours de ce cycle Mme Bintou  compte réaliser  145 000FCFA.  
En plus du remboursement des prêts, elles utilisent une partie du revenu  pour faire face aux dépenses personnelles et augmenter son fonds de commerce. 
Elles souhaitent voir renforcer ce partenariat avec  Soro Yiriwaso pour que les stocks ne soient pas rares.
texts.en:
Yiriwa is a group of women from the Hamdallaye neighborhood of the city of Koutiala. These women know each other well and live in large, traditional families with their husbands, children, and other relatives. They average 36 years old, are married, and all have at least 3 children. 

This group of women sells a variety of items such as clothing, condiments and other products. The members of the Yiriwa group decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program to increase their business activity. This is their thirteenth group loan. 

Bintou [seated second from the right] is a member of the Yiriwa group and sells Soumbala [a condiment made from the fermented seeds of the locust tree]. She plans on using her loan to buy a large amount of high-quality soumbala at the market which she will then retail to a diverse group of customers. While the other members of the Yiriwa group plan on earning an average income of 130,000 CFA Francs each during this cycle, Bintou plans on earning 145,000 CFA Francs. In addition to repaying loans, the women also use some of their income to cover personal expenses and to increase their business capital. They hope to strengthen their partnership with Soro Yiriwaso so that they will always have inventory to sell.

loans.use: to buy soumbala [condiment made from fermented seeds].

loans.name: Camilo

texts.en:
Camilo is 52 years old, married, and has three children. As a way of generating income, he has been engaged in a variety store business within his community in Manila, Philippines for eight years now. Together with his wife, he works hard to provide for the everyday needs of their family.

In the Philippines, a variety store is a retail store that sells inexpensive items, often with a single price for all items in the store. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Camilo earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by piece. His regular customers are his neighbors and the local community. He earns a minimum of Php 500 in sales every day.

Due to financial insufficiency, Camilo wants to make his business more profitable in order to earn a higher income. For this reason, he would like to access a loan amounting to 20,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) to buy additional grocery items that are needed. He is hoping that he will further improve the business through this financial assistance.

Camilo hopes for his business to prosper and for his family to be always in good hands. He meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his life and business every week and draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God he studies.

*All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in his business.

loans.name: Angela

texts.en:
Angela is 34 years old and has four children. Angela is married and her four children are in school.

Angela is in the agricultural business, raising livestock in the Philippines. Angela requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional livestock, feed and vitamins for her livestock.

Angela has been raising livestock for eight years now, and has borrowed three times in the past from NWTF to sustain the business.

In the future, Angela would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional livestock, feed and vitamins for her livestock

loans.name: Avelina

texts.en: Avelina works hard to support her family. She has a live-in partner and earns her income by selling ready-to-wear items in the Philippines. She is requesting a  loan for PHP 12,000 from NWTF to buy additional items to sell, including sandals and blouses. She has been in business for ten years, and supplements her income by selling Avon products. In the future, Avelina would like to save enough money to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional ready-to-wear items to sell.

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en: Cecilia is 57 years old and married with one child. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur who earns a living by raising livestock in the Philippines. She has requested a PHP 60,000 loan from NWTF to buy additional livestock, vitamins, feed and other supplies for her business. Cecilia has been in her current line of work for three years and would like to save enough to provide a secure future to her family.

loans.use: to buy additional livestock, vitamins, feed, and other supplies for her business

loans.name: Yunis

texts.es: Yunis con su credikiva anterior pudo invertir en comprar telas y atender el cien por ciento de los requerimientos de sus clientes, pudiendo lograr mayores utilidades;  gracias a esta inversión, su vida tiene un mejoramiento porque adecuó su vivienda. Ella da las gracias a sus financiadores por la ayuda realizada y planea aplicar  a su nuevo credikiva, mediante el cual comprará insumos de confecciones como telas y mercancías variadas. Con esta inversión pronto tendrá nuevas utilidades.
texts.en: Yunis was able to purchase more cloth and to satisfy 100% of her clients needs with her previous loan. Thanks to the previous loan, her life is improving.  She has also been able to make some home improvements. She is thankful to the lenders at Kiva for their help and she is applying for a new loan, which she will use to purchase more supplies like cloths and various other products. This loan will bring her higher profits.

loans.use: purchase cloth and other merchandise.

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James lives in Hoima, Uganda. He is aged 33, married with three children, aged between 4 and 9. He operates  a bar and is a wholesaler of packaged alcohol, plus getting more money from a motorcycle transport (boda boda) business. He started  business so as to improve his household income. He dreams of educating his children and purchasing plots of land for investment but he lacks enough capital.

James is accessing credit to buy more alcohol to sell to his clients.

loans.use: to buy more alcohol to sell to his clients.

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Richard is a 30-year-old, hard-working married man with two children, ages 1 and 4, who lives in Kamwenge, Uganda. He sells maize, beans and coffee as his main source of income. He started this business to have a better life. He faces a challenge of competition and weather changes that affect his produce business. He has a vision of owning a big modern produce store and catering to his family's needs.

He is requesting a loan to buy more maize, beans and coffee to sell.

loans.use: to buy more maize, beans and coffee to sell.

loans.name: Jackline

texts.en:
Jackline is a 32-year-old hard-working married woman living in Kamwenge, Uganda. She sells second-hand clothes as her main source of income. The main reason for venturing into this business was to cater to her family's needs. She faces a challenge of competition and seasonal markets for her clothes. She has hopes of owning a wholesale modern boutique in her area.

Jackline is requesting a loan to buy more second-hand clothes to sell.

loans.use: to buy more second-hand clothes to sell.

loans.name: Yasoni

texts.en: Yasoni is 54, married and lives in Masindi, Uganda. He sells general merchandise as his main source of income. He also does farming to supplement his income after realizing that proceeds from his retail trade alone could not fully meet his family's needs. He has hopes of educating his children despite  being challenged by inadequate capital. Yasoni will use the loan to buy general merchandise like sugar, salt, soda and soap to sell.

loans.use: to buy general merchandise like sugar, salt, soda and soap to sell.

loans.name: Joan

texts.en: Joan lives in Hoima, Uganda. She is 27 years old, married and the mother of two children who are 1 and 5 years old. She earns a living by running a beauty salon where she works seven days a week. She started her business in 2012 to earn money to educate her children. Her customers are women who live in her town, and although she hopes to expand her business, competition is a big challenge. Joan will use this loan to buy weaves to sell to her customers.

loans.use: to buy hair weaves to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Elankatchiamman Shg Group

texts.en:
Jeeva is the member of “Elankatchiamman” Self Help Group along with seven other members in Koothangudi village.  She is 29 years old and married to Murali. He is a daily wage worker in the agriculture fields. They are living in their own house with two children. 

The group has taken loans from “PAT” before and repaid them on time. The loans have helped them improve their income. Now, all the group members plan to buy smokeless stoves for their kitchens, for which they are seeking the loan. All these women use firewood convention stoves for which inefficiently solid biomass fuels like wood are burned and more trees and vegetation are cut down. The depletion of forests in turn destroys soil quality and agriculture land. They are grateful to the lenders for giving them a chance to have a healthier life.

loans.use: to buy smokeless stove

loans.name: Annabelle

texts.en:
Annabelle works hard to support her family. She is married and has a dress-making business in the Philippines.

Annabelle requested a PHP 13,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional materials like fabric, thread, buttons, zippers, etc. for her business. She has been in this business for 35 years now.

In the future, Annabelle would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional materials like fabric, thread, buttons, zippers, etc. for her business

loans.name: Cristita

texts.en: Cristita is married and earns a living by selling fish in the Philippines. She has requested a loan for PHP 11,000 from NWTF to buy more items to sell from her stall. She has been in her current line of work for four years and would like to secure her family's future by improving and expanding her business.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy fertilizer and seeds to prepare the land

loans.name: Edwina

texts.en:
As a married parent of five children, Edwina works hard to support her family. She has a manicure/pedicure service in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from direct selling of personal collection products. Edwina is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to buy more materials for her manicure/pedicure business.

Edwina has been sustaining her business activities through her past four loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy more materials for her manicure/pedicure business

loans.name: Florame

texts.en:
Florame is 35 years old and married with five children. With four children currently in school, Florame works very hard to provide for them.

Florame runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more items like snack foods, soft drinks, cooking oil, noodles and other groceries to sell.

Florame has been in this business for three years and sells a variety of items such as snack foods, soft drinks, cooking oil, noodles and other groceries. 

In the future, Florame would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to school.

loans.use: to purchase more items like snack foods, soft drinks, cooking oil, noodles and other groceries to sell

loans.name: Jean

texts.en:
Jean is 30 years old and married with two children. With one child currently in school, Jean works very hard to provide for them.

Jean runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 16,000 loan through NWTF to buy more stock to sell in her general store.

Jean has been in this business for 10 years and sells a variety of items such as cereals, chocolate drink, beer, soft drinks, detergent soap, etc. 

Jean would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy more stock to sell in her general store

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
Josefina is a married woman with eight children. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. Josefina is 63 years old and has one child who is still in school.

Josefina has a buy-and-sell dry goods business in the Philippines. Josefina requested a PHP 13,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy more stock of dry goods like pillows, shorts, T-shirts, etc. to sell.

Josefina has been in this business for 10 years. In the future, Josefina would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more stock of dry goods like pillows, shorts, T-shirts, etc. to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchase cows.

loans.name: Marcos Antonio

texts.es:
Marcos tiene 53 años de edad, realizó sus estudios hasta el 5 grado de educación básica, está casado desde hace mas de 20 años y su esposa es comerciante de pescado, viven junto a un hijo quien está estudiando 6 grado. 


Marcos es pescador artesanal, tenia 5 años de edad cuando comenzó a ir a trabajar con su padre en la pesca, desde entonces ese ha sido el negocio al se ha dedicado, y sus esposa le ayuda en la venta la mercadería que él trae del mar, además de su hijo que se involucra en los tiempos libres.  

El préstamo será utilizado para comprar materiales para la elaboración de redes de pesca, pues las que tiene ya se le están deteriorando y necesita tener buen equipo de trabajo.  


Él espera enseñarle bien el trabajo a su hijo, pero también quiere que su hijo se prepare académicamente y que logre sacar una carrera profesional, ya que él no lo pudo hacer y quiere que su hijo si lo logre.
texts.en:
Marcos is 53 years old. He was able to finish his schooling up to the 5th grade. He has been married for 20 years and his wife sells fish. They live with their son who is in the 6th grade. 

Marcos is a traditional fisherman. He was five years old when he began to work alongside his father. Ever since, he has practiced his trade and his wife helps him sell what he catches. His son also lends a hand in his spare time. 

The loan will be used to purchase materials to make fishing nets because the ones he currently uses are deteriorating and he needs better equipment in order to do a better job.  

He hopes to teach his son the family business, but he also wants his son to go to school so he can have a professional career. Marcos was unable to continue his own schooling and so he wants his son to be able to achieve this.

loans.use: purchase materials to make fishing nets.

loans.name: Marina

texts.es:
Marina de 51 años de edad, es una mujer trabajadora que ha luchado por sacar a sus hijos adelante por sus propios medios ya que es una madre soltera, sus hijos ya son mayores de edad pero viven junto a ella y también tiene un nieto que ella junto a su hija lo están criando. 


Desde hace mas de 30 años, Marina hace venta de antojitos para salir a vender casa por casa, cuenta con muchos años de experiencia y solo una hija se involucra y le ayuda en la venta.


El préstamo que está solicitando lo necesita para comprar mercadería para su negocio de venta de antojitos ya que quiere diversificarlo, ahora quiere dedicarse también a la venta de plásticos ( platos , huacales, etc) ya que ha hecho sus proyecciones y considera que le dará ganancias.

Su sueño es construir su propia casa ya que en la que vive es de un familiar, ella piensa trabajar duro y con el apoyo de sus hijos poder salir adelante y cumplir ese sueño.
texts.en:
51 year old Marina is a hardworking woman who has fought to raise her children on her own as she is a single mother. Her children are grownup but live with her and she also has a grandson who she is raising with her daughter. 
For more than 30 years, Marina has made and sold antojitos (street food) to sell door to door. She has many years of experience and one of her daughters helps her with the sales. 
She needs the loan she is requesting to buy supplies for her business selling antojitos as she wants to diversify. Now she wants to also sell plastic goods (plates, crates, etc) as she has done the calculations and believes that this would be profitable.
Her dream is to build her own house as the house she lives in belongs to a relative. She thinks that if she works hard and has the help of her children, she can be successful and realize this dream.

loans.use: to buy supplies for her business selling antojitos (street food) as she wants to diversify.

loans.name: Deepam Shg Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Manjula is a member of Deepam Self Help Group (SHG) along with six other women. She lives in a small hamlet in the rural area of Kathiramangalam in Tanjore District, Tamil Nadu. She is married to Mr. Ramesh. They have two children, both studying. They live in a house made with a thatched roof. 

Manjula and her group members have received loans from PAT before and have paid their dues promptly on time.
 
Household air pollution produced by cooking indoors with biomass fuels on open fires or cook stoves is the number one health risk factor in India. It causes lung cancer, chronic heart and lung diseases, meningitis and low birth weight in infants.
 
Manjula and her group members are looking forward to getting this “Kiva” loan to purchase a smokeless stove to use in their kitchen, which will help them to breathe fresh air.

loans.use: to buy a smokeless stove

loans.name: Rahila

texts.ru:
Рахила одна из женщин, которые занимаются скотоводством. На протяжении тридцати лет она разводит коров и овец, доит коров и продаёт молоко. На полученный доход покупает продукты, тратит на детей, покупая необходимые вещи и оплачивая обучение. У Рахилы семеро детей. Они все уже взрослые и помогают маме по хозяйству и в скотоводстве. Сыновья выводят коров на пастбище, дочка помогает доить коров. Муж Рахилы занимается дехканским хозяйством. У него земельный участок, где выращивает зерновые культуры и овощи. 
Семья Рахили решили купить корову и корм для них. На данный момент Рахила не имеет нужную сумму в руках,так как еще не продала коров, а доходы от молока тратит на текущие расходы. С целью приобрести денежные средства Рахила обратилась за кредитом в ООО МДО "Арванд". Очень надеется, что она получит запрашиваемую сумму  и она сможет осуществит свои планы в реальность. Заранее благодарит за содействие и поддержку.
texts.en:
Rahila is one of those women, who are involved in animal husbandry. She has been breeding cows and sheep, milking cows and selling milk for thirty years. She uses the business income to buy products, spend for her children by buying necessary things and paying for education. Rahila has seven children. All of them are already grown and help their mother with the household and business. The sons take cattle to a pasture, and daughter helps milk the cows. Rahila's husband is involved in dekhan farming. He has a land plot, where he grows cereal crops and vegetables.

Rahila's family decided to buy a cow and livestock feed. At the present time, Rahila does not have the necessary amount of money in hand because she has not yet sold cows and spends the income from selling milk on ongoing expenses. Rahila came to MDO Arvand to obtain a loan. She very much hopes to receive the requested sum and be able to realize her plans. She is grateful in advance for the help and support.

loans.use: to buy a cow and livestock feed

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for renovations and improvements to his bakery.

loans.name: Mehriniso

texts.ru: Мехринисо является мастером своего дела.  Она родилась в 1961 году. Мехринисо опытная портниха и создает шедевры таджикских национальных платьев.  Она замужем и на воспитании имеет  5 детей. С целью обеспечения семьи со всеми необходимыми средствами 28 лет назад она начала свой бизнес. Она предоставляет свои услуги у себя дома. Благодаря  хорошему сервису, она обладает широким кругом клиентов. Ее клиенты женщины со вкусом и очень трудно их удовлетворять, но Мехринисо с легкостью справляется с их капризами. Она хочет купить ткани для увеличения оборотного капитала и с такой целью она запрашивает займ на сумму 3000 сомони. Она надеется на вас и вашу доброту.
texts.en: Mehriniso is an expert in her business. She was born in 1961. Mehriniso is an experienced seamstress and creates Tajik national dress masterpieces. She is married and raising 5 children. She started her own business 28 years ago to provide her family with all of the necessities. She provides her services at home. Thanks to good service, she has a wide circle of clients. Her clients are women with taste, who are difficult to please, but Mehriniso deals with their whims with ease. She wants to purchase fabrics to increase her working capital and is requesting a loan in the amount of 3000 somoni for this purpose. She relies on you and your kindness.

loans.use: to purchase fabrics and increase her working capital

loans.name: David

texts.es:
David es un hombre de 33 años de edad soltero y sin hijos.
Su actividad diaria es la venta de comida, almuerzo y cena, desde muy joven aprendió a cocinar y a trabajar para ayudar a su familia; “cuando era joven asistía a la escuela por la tarde, terminaban mis clases y me dirigía rápidamente a mi trabajo que era la venta de hamburguesas”, de esa manera pudo terminar la escuela secundaria y continuo sus estudios en la escuela hotelera la cual tuvo que abandonar por motivos económicos.
En la actualidad se encarga de la venta de comida a personas en sus oficinas y trabajos trasladando diariamente almuerzo y cena a sus lugares de trabajo.
Los insumos que compra los hace diariamente porque no cuenta con el capital económico necesario para comprar por mayor. Su vida está llena de sueños e ilusiones, el campo gastronómico es su fuerte y su ideal es tener su propia churrasquería grande y atender a sus clientes a diario.
Es por esos motivos que David solicita un préstamo para la compra de insumos por mayor.
texts.en:
David is a 33-year-old man who is single and has no children. His daily business involves selling food, including lunches and dinners. At a very young age, he learned how to cook so that he could work in order to support his family. “When I was younger, I attended school in the afternoons. When I finished my classes, I promptly went to my job of selling hamburgers,” says David. This allowed him to finish high school and continue on to studying at a school for hotel management. However, he had to quit because of financial reasons.

David currently sells food to people who work in offices or are passing through the area. Every day he delivers lunches and dinners to various workplaces. He buys his supplies on a daily basis because he does not have enough capital to buy in bulk.

His life is full of hopes and dreams. The food industry is his strong suit, so his ideal wish is to open a large steakhouse where he can serve his customers every day. It for these reasons that David requests a loan for buying supplies in bulk.

loans.use: to buy supplies in bulk for his food business.

loans.name: Franklin

texts.es:
Franklin es un hombre de 31 años de edad soltero y sin hijos.
Él vive en una comunidad campesina llamada Isla Suriqui, la actividad principal de los comunarios del lugar es la pesca la cual se realiza día a día. Sus conocimientos escolares son primarios y básicos a pesar de ello él cuenta con varias metas e ideas de negocios comerciales una de ellas consiste en el traslado de personas y alimentos a través de valsas o botes; “He visto la necesidad de transportar nuestras artesanías y pescados con mayor rapidez a otras comunidades”, comenta franklin.
Franklin aprendió carpintería cuando realizaba su servicio militar también construyó gran parte de la casa donde vive actualmente y ahora tiene la idea de emprender un nuevo negocio como transportista valsero, ya que los botes de su comunidad son utilizados en su mayoría para la pesca con red.
Franklin está convencido que su nuevo emprendimiento será un éxito porque existe la necesidad y él está decidido a cubrirla para posteriormente crear una flota de valsas y botes.
Es por esos motivos que Franklin solicita un préstamo para la compra de madera para su nuevo negocio.
texts.en:
Franklin is a 31 year old man who is single and doesn't have kids.
He lives in a rural community called Isla Suriqui. The main activity of the people in the community is fishing, and they do this everyday. He had only a basic primary education but, in spite of this, he has various goals and ideas for businesses. One of these is to transport people and food by boat. "I have seen the need to transport our crafts and fish more quickly to other communities", he comments.
Franklin learned carpentry when he was doing his military service and he also built a large part of the house where he currently lives. Now he has an idea to start a new transportation business as the boats in the community are used for the most part for net fishing.
Franklin is convinced that his new enterprise will be a success because there is a need and he has decided to pursue it and later create a fleet of boats. 
For these reasons, Franklin is requesting a loan to buy wood for his new business.

loans.use: to buy wood

loans.name: Muminjon

texts.ru: Муминчон перспективный молодой человек. У него свой бизнес. На центральном базаре "Бадри Мунир" имеет магазин женской обуви. Десять лет назад, когда начинал свое дело, ему доставляли товар купцы, а теперь сам привозит обувь с Бишкека и продает. Начинал с малого, ассортимент обуви было не велико. Постепенно, тратя заработанные деньги с умом смог расширит ассортимент и создать свою клиентскую базу..В бизнесе его поддерживает его семья. У него любящая  жена и несмотря на свое молодость  имеет двоих прекрасных детей. Молодой дважды папа старается чтоб его семья и дети не в чем не нуждались.У него высшее образование, но в связи с трудностями на рынке труда,не стал ждать подходящей работы и открыл свой бизнес. Теперь когда дела идут хорошо, ему понадобились деньги для оборота, и так он решил получить нужную не достающую   сумму в кредит и на полученный кредит хочет купить новый ассортимент женской обуви.  С этой целью обратился в МДО "Арванд" . Благодарит заранее всех за помощь и поддержку.
texts.en: Muminjon is a promising young man. He has his own business. He has a women's shoe store at the "Badri Munir" central market. Ten years ago, when he first started his business, distributors brought merchandise to him, and now he brings shoes himself from Bishkek and sells them. He started with very little and a small selection of shoes. Gradually and spending earned money wisely, he was able to expand his selection and create his own client base. His family supports him in this business. He has a loving wife and, despite his young age, two beautiful children. The young father tries to ensure that his family and children were not in need for anything. He has a higher education, but due to market difficulties, decided not to wait for a suitable job and started his own business. Now with things going well, he needs money for goods turnover, and he decided to obtain the necessary remaining amount as a loan to purchase a new selection of women's shoes. He came to MDO Arvand to fulfill this goal. He thanks everyone in advance for help and support.

loans.use: to purchase a new selection of women's shoes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to market her business, buy equipment and create a new marketing platform

loans.name: Marikolunthu Shg Group

texts.en:
Gnanasownthari is the team leader and a member of Marikolunthu Self Help Group, which was formed by the NGO, People Action for Transformation (PAT) in Tamil Nadu, India. She lives in Alambadi village in Trichurapalli district.

Gnanasownthari is 50 years old and lives in her own house with her two children and husband, Kasper. He is a small farmer in a village. Gnanasownthari has been receiving loans from “PAT” regularly for five years now and each time, she repaid it on time. She had taken the loans for the development of their land and to increase the yield.

Gnanasownthari needs a loan to purchase a smokeless stove to save time and money. The traditional stoves require more time to collect fuel or she must use her family income to pay someone else to collect it. The inefficient use of the fuel causes a high time or monetary burden and creates many problems like health, deforestation, quality of life and climate change.

loans.use: to buy a smokeless stove

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine works hard to support her family. She is widowed and has a  business selling frozen foods in the Philippines.

Josephine requested a PHP 13,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more packs of frozen foods to sell.

Josephine has been in this business for 10 years now.

Josephine would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more packs of frozen foods to sell

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en:
Lourdes is 50 years old and married with six children. With one child still in school, Lourdes works very hard to provide for them.

Lourdes runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more groceries to sell in her general store.

Lourdes has been in this business for three years and sells a variety of items such as noodles, canned goods, soft drinks, coffee, sugar, etc. 

In the future, Lourdes would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell in her general store

loans.name: Godfrey

texts.en:
Godfrey lives in Hoima, Uganda. He is aged 38, married, with five children aged between 7 and 15; all attend school. He has a motorcycle transport (boda boda) business which works 7 days a week and 12 hours a day. He earns additional income from his monthly salary. 

He started business to improve his financial status. His clients are the general public of Hoima town. His dream is to have an educated family. The challenge he faces is competition. He is acquiring credit to pay school fees for his children.

loans.use: to pay school fees for his children.

loans.name: Sauda

texts.en: Sauda lives in Hoima, Uganda. She is a single hardworking  mother  aged 47, with one child aged 17 who attends school. She started business in 2002 in the central market and sells fresh foods to enable her to take care of her family. Her dream is to see her business grow into a grocery shop. Her challenges are too few customers and bad debtors. She is  acquiring a loan to buy pineapples, oranges and garlic for sale.

loans.use: to buy pineapples, oranges and garlic to sell

loans.name: Jerome

texts.en:
Twenty-nine-year-old Jerome lives in Hoima, Uganda. He is a hardworking married man with two children, aged one and four. He started business (a retail shop) in 2008 so as to become self-employed. He gets side income from rentals (two rooms). His dreams are to move to an urban area and educate his children. The challenges are inadequate capital and price fluctuations.

Jerome is acquiring a loan to buy sugar, salt, and other general merchandise to sell.

loans.use: buy sugar, salt, and other general merchandise items to sell

loans.name: Henrri Antonio

texts.es:
Henrri es un joven trabajador de 26 años de edad, quien estudió noveno grado de educación básica, tiene 2 años de estar acompañado, tiene un hijo de 1 año de edad y viven con sus padres, hermanos y esposa.


Henrri trabaja en un supermercado en la localidad a 2 cuadras de su casa desde hace 2 años, anteriormente él trabajaba junto a su papá en la agricultura, luego de acompañarse con su compañera de vida decidió buscar un trabajo mas estable y que le generara mayores ingresos para él y su familia y encontró uno cerca de su casa    


El préstamo que él está solicitando es para el mejoramiento de la vivienda y así darles una mejor seguridad a su familia.

Su sueño es tener una familia unida y poder brindar a su hijo y a los que están por venir tengan la mejor educación y que no les falte lo necesario.
texts.en:
Henrri es a hardworking young man of 26 years of age who studied through to 9th grade. He has had a partner for 2 years and has a 1 year old son. He lives with his parents, brother, and wife.
Henrri works in a local supermarket 2 blocks from his house and has done so for 2 years. Before that he worked with his father in agriculture. Later, along with his partner, he decided to look for more stable work that brings in more income for him and his family and he found work close to home. 
He will use the loan that his is requesting for making improvements to his house and, in doing so, will give his family greater security. 
His dream is to have a united family and to be able to offer his son and children to come a good education and make sure that they lack for nothing.

loans.use: to improve his house and give his family greater security.

loans.name: Reginald

texts.en:
On the job as an emergency medical technician, Reginald saw a need in his community in Houston. Wheel-chair bound people need access to vans like the EMT vehicles he drove, not just during medical emergencies, but to get to doctor’s appointments, to accomplish tasks and to get to events.

So after saving money and buying a van equipped with a wheelchair lift, Reginald started operating his business, Quality Performance Transportation, this February. Reginald said what sets his company apart from other transportation companies serving wheelchair bound individuals is personalized service.

“We conform to the needs of the individual,” Reginald said. “We might have a patient that needs more assistance, say the patient is at the doctor’s office, we take notes and provide the notes to the caretaker. We have another client, and all that this particular client needs is for us to be precisely on time so he’s not waiting. We do what the patient needs to have done.”

Reginald received a small business loan from Accion Texas for marketing and working capital. With some of the money, Reginald invested in creating a direct-mail flyer that he started sending out to potential clients this June. 

He said within two weeks of sending out the flyers, his business is already on track to triple the net revenue. Before the direct-mail campaign started, the company was pulling in $700 to $900 a month. Within two weeks of mailing out the flyer, he said the company generated $1,200 of business.
“We’re able to breathe a little and it’s nice,” he said.
 
Reginald said he is plan is to continue sending out direct mail flyers to clients, and then buy another van in six months, and perhaps approach Accion Texas with another loan to expand his business.

loans.use: to pay for advertising

loans.name: Jose Luis

texts.es: Jose tiene 44 años de edad, Jose es un señor casado y vive con 4 de sus 6 hijos, el  juntamente a sus hijos se dedican a la agricultura, el credito lo va a invertir en la compra de fungicidas y abono para tener sanos sus cultivos, Jose en verdad necesita el credito ya que en el lugar donde tiene sus cultivos esta un clima muy cambiante y si no funiga sus plantas se le pueden dañar, Jose tiene  la esperanza de tener una buena cosecha y por medio de estos ingresos mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia.
texts.en: Jose is 44 years old. He is married and lives with 4 of his 6 children. Along with his sons, he works in agriculture. The loan will be used to buy fungicides and fertilizer to keep his crops healthy. In truth, Jose needs the loan because the place where he has his land has a very changeable climate and if he doesn't protect his plants with fungicide they can be damaged. Jose has the experience to have a good harvest and, with these supplies, to improve his family's quality of life.

loans.use: to buy fungicide.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase inventory for a large wholesale order and hire an employee

loans.name: Oswaldo

texts.es:
Oswaldo tiene 46 años de edad, vive con su cónyuge y su hijo en el Distrito de Santo Tomás, una comunidad de clima variado, ubicado cerca a un parque de Reserva con abundante vegetación y fauna, de paisajes verdes, su relieve es accidentado lo que le ha permitido desarrollarse mediante la agricultura, comercio y ganadería, ubicada en la Provincia de Cutervo que pertenece a la Región Cajamarca, sierra norte del Perú.

El se dedica a la venta y preparación de parihuelas, ceviches, abasteciéndose de insumos desde Jaén, realiza sus pedidos todos los fines de semana para ofrecerlo a sus clientes los días domingos que es el día de mayor comercio en el distrito, su negocio se encuentra ubicada en su domicilio, también se desempeña como profesor de Educción Física en el colegio secundario de su Distrito.

Ha solicitado un préstamo a Edpyme Alternativa de 1 500 nuevos soles para la compra de variedad de pescados, así como vajilla descartable para ofrecer un servicio más oportuno para sus clientes.
texts.en:
Oswaldo is 46 years old and lives with his wife and son in the District of Santo Tomás, a community that has a varied climate. It located near a park reserve that has abundant vegetation and wildlife, as well as green landscapes. The mountainous terrain is rugged, but industries such as agriculture, trade, and livestock breeding are still able to thrive. This area is located in Cutero Province, which is part of the region of Cajamarca in the northern mountains of Peru.

Oswaldo prepares and sells seafood stews and “ceviches” (dishes that contain seafood marinated in citrus juice), so he must obtain his supplies in Jaén. He takes orders every weekend so that he can offer his dishes to his customers. Sunday is the day when the most business occurs in his district. Oscar’s business is located in his home, but he also teaches physical education at a high school in his district.

He is requesting a loan from Edpyme Alternativa in the amount of 1,500 PEN so that he can buy a variety of fish. He will also buy disposable dishware so that he can offer more timely service to his customers.

loans.use: to buy a variety of fish and disposable dishware for serving food.

loans.name: Ben Group

texts.fr:
Ben est un regroupement de femmes du quartier Koulikoro de la ville de Koutiala qui se connaissent bien et qui vivent dans de grandes familles traditionnelles avec leurs maris, enfants et autres parents. Elles ont en moyenne 33 ans, sont mariées et ont au moins 4 enfants.
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles divers tels que, des Habits, Bois de chauffage et divers. Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso. Elles sont à leur huitième prêt de groupe. 
Mariam  est un membre du groupe Ben debout devant, habillée en Bazin bleu foncée, vendeuse de Bois de chauffe.  Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter de Chargements de bois dans des brousses environnantes de Koutiala en quantité et en qualité qu’elle vend en détail  à une clientèle diverse. 
Tandis que les autres membres du groupe Ben comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 100 000FCFA  chacune au  cours de ce cycle Mme Mariam  compte réaliser  115 000FCFA.  
En plus du remboursement des prêts, elles utilisent une partie du revenu  pour faire face aux dépenses personnelles et augmenter son fonds de commerce. 
Elles souhaitent voir renforcer ce partenariat avec  Soro Yiriwaso pour que les stocks ne soient pas rares.
texts.en:
Ben is a group of women from the Koulikoro neighborhood of the city of Koutiala. They know each other well and live in large, traditional families with their husbands, children, and other relatives. They average 33 years old, are married, and all have at least 4 children. 

This group of women sells various items such as clothing, firewood, and sundries. The group members decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program in order to increase their business. This is their eighth group loan. 

Mariam (standing in front, dressed in dark blue damask) is a member of the Ben group and sells firewood. She plans on using her loan to buy large loads of high-quality wood in the brush land near Koutiala that she will retail to a diverse clientele.

While the other members of the Ben group plan on earning an average income of 100,000 CFA Francs each during this cycle, Mariam plans on earning 115,000 CFA Francs. In addition to repaying loans, the women use part of their income to cover personal expenses and to increase their business capital. They hope to strengthen their partnership with Soro Yiriwaso so that they always have inventory to sell.

loans.use: to buy firewood.

loans.name: Lucena

texts.en:
Lucena works hard to support her family. She is married and has a fruit and vegetable vending business in the Philippines.

Lucena requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy more fruit and vegetables to sell to her customers. She has been in this business for six years now. She successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business.

Lucena would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy more fruits and vegetables to sell to her customers

loans.name: Michael

texts.en:
Mike and Sharon’s journey to start and grow Double Time Express exemplifies the idea of American persistence and grit. Mike grew up with his mother on a farm with dreams of making a living working the land. That all changed when his mother died, sending him to the city to live with his father, far away from the agricultural community that was all he knew.

At 18, Mike joined the Marines, which is where he first started driving trucks.
